job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Vancouver, BC
pros: As a new grad nurse I felt well supported by the company. They offered multiple training workshops that you can sign up for depending on what unit you wanted to work. I was able to extend the amount of buddy shifts that I had until I felt more comfortable to work on the unit by myself. They have a new grad mentor that you are able to call/text if you have questions and will try to show up on the unit to help guide you. For example, I did my first packing wound and I didn't want to bother other nurses on the floor so I was able to have a new grad mentor with me which definitely made me feel more confident. They also have benefits for part time staff. They use Cerner which is computerized charting and it makes finding information so much more easier compared to paper, where you have to chase after binders.
cons: - they are usually short staffed. Usually your work load is 1:4 patients when you are short sometimes you can have up to 5 or 6. - There is a lot of redeployment to different units if you are regular staff which can be annoying when you go to a unit early to do research and then end up being redeployed and receiving report from 4 different nurses.

review_title: PHC is an institution in BC and for the rest of the world in providing best medical care to patients and families.’
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Vancouver, BC
pros:
Academic hospital. They value on personal and professional development.
Developed a close knit family atmosphere amongst workers. 
Its a Catholic Hospital. Beliefs and spirituality are respected. 
PHC is one of the first Health Authorities to advocate for the inclusion of the marginalized population especially those who are suffering from mental health illness and addiction. 
Lots of support for new employees.
Educational opportunities.
Approachable supervisors and managers.
cons:
Pressure coming higher management on keeping up with the number of patients we see. 
Hierarchical working environment which can lead to toxic working environment. 
Roles and duties performed can be redundant.

review_title: 'How you want to be treated' goes beyond patient care - it starts with those who care for the patients.
pros: It's a state of mind that seems to filter down from leadership positions that inspires staff to be their best. It's no secret that staff with good morale extend that care to their patients and is reciprocal. PHC embodies this philosophy wholeheartedly.
cons: It would be useful to have more expressive and artistic therapeutic opportunities for the patients to help sustain wellness outside the hospital setting if it were tied into a long term care plan after discharge. This would, in turn, increase the career opportunities, not to mention less re-admissions.  Win-win-win!

pros: Working at St. Paul's Hospital can be a rewarding experience. The ward I worked on didn't feel corporate, and decisions were largely made by consortium of interests: everybody had an opportunity to weigh in. It didn't feel hierarchical. So much passion, dedication and compassionate bedside manners. Truly an awesome experience.
cons: There isn't much room to move up if you are a social worker. Most mid-management and upper management jobs are held by nurses. Still, you are not discouraged to apply for those jobs.

pros:
The people are amazing! From the CEO Diane all the way down to the front line. Everyone really is a family and works together for the greater good which is providing exceptional and compassionate care to patients and residents. 
Such a warm, kind, caring, fair and respectful place to work. You are lucky if you work here!
cons: Not alot of turnover (which shows how great of a place it is to work) but that means no vacant senior roles and highly competitive when senior roles do come up.  It is difficult to move up and limited funding for training or mentorship etc so if you have a desire to climb the ladder it could take a while.

pros: Love this company! Really enjoy being in charge of my own schedule. The Union reps are awesome! All managers I have seen or heard of was all positive.
cons: Sometimes I do not get enough hours per month. Also getting a call at 9PM to go into work at 11PM is not very fun! But work is work so it's not that bad! It's hard to even think of any cons.

pros:
If you are looking for a job you can live on and it doesn't really matter how much you make and you enjoy filing and working with information, go for it! Even as a clerk, you will need to use your brain quite a lot and certain aspects of the job keep you sharp and you may develop a great variety of aptitudes in a short amount of time, especially if you are an employee of a casual status. 
 
As a casual employee, you get the option of customizing your schedule somewhat. This is very useful for people with other obligations. But if you are casual, you do not get benefits. So, essentially, being a casual means getting more freedom and learning a greater variety of clerical skills in exchange for less money, fewer working hours, and the odd phone call in the wee hours of the morning.
cons:
As a clerk, you are also:

-a manager when the manager isn't there
-a staff trainer on procedures and policy
-a supervisor
-a departmental exec decision maker when no one is available
-the face that takes the brunt of abuse from angry clients
-repair-person and consultant for when computers, printers, scanners break down

It's nice to get that experience, but the problem is that, in the end, you still get paid and treated as just a clerk, which is somewhat insulting, frankly, when admin assistants often make 2x what clerks make for PHC (gross annual, ~$25,000 for clerks vs $40,000+ for admin assistants).

The consolation is that "you should be glad you have a job at all", and that's the sentiment that keeps a lot of these clerks going.

As for the company, it wastes $ like no tomorrow, makes terrible judgment calls on spending (not thinking things through and having to backtrack more than they should); overpays its higher ups, complains there's no money, and to 'solve this' problem it cuts the pay of their lowest-paid employees, privatizes services (such as transcription, for instance, which they said would save them 3 million; clerks lost their jobs and "somehow" the private transcription company is filing for bankruptcy), and seem to put the most strain on its lowest-paid people. It also lowered the educational standards for clerks, who now may be accepted into clerical positions without pertinent education or experience, which seems to justify the salary, but you have to remember that those of us that went to school paid thousands of dollars and some of us spent 2 years of our lives just to get this position.

pros:
Access to benefits - great extended health benefits plans. Job security - Union allows for some level of protection from volatility.
Strength in numbers - large groups of peers for support
cons:
Working in a unionized environment fosters a lack of effort. Many will scrape by doing the bare minimum.
Also, for an individual who looks for performance based compensation - there is no room for growth in a union.
